Demon Slayer: Mugen Train is the best movie ever made. This anime film takes the audience on an emotional roller coaster ride, leaving them in awe of the stunning visuals, captivating storytelling, and unforgettable characters.


The plot follows the demon slayer Tanjiro and his companions as they board the Mugen Train to investigate a series of disappearances. The film masterfully weaves action and drama, with heart-wrenching moments that will have you reaching for the tissues.


The animation is breathtaking, with vivid colors and fluid action sequences that leave you on the edge of your seat. The sound design is equally impressive, with an epic score that sets the tone for each scene.


But what truly sets Demon Slayer: Mugen Train apart is its characters. Each one is fleshed out and given their own unique backstory, making it easy for the audience to become invested in their journey.


Overall, Demon Slayer: Mugen Train is a masterpiece. It's a must-watch for anime fans and movie-goers alike. The film will leave you wanting more, eagerly anticipating the next installment in the series.

This movie is extremely overrated. I have nothing against anime and I went in with low expectations, but the movie still disappointed me and was painful to get through, at least until the climax. While the animation was impressive, it's not significantly better than many other high-quality animes and pre-CGI American animations. And while the final fight was somewhat cool (although definitely overrated), it doesn't make up for an hour and a half of nonsensical fighting where the main protagonist has loads of plot armor, pointless monologuing that adds nothing to the plot and only states the obvious, and terrible jokes and visual gags that were some of the most cringe-worthy I've ever heard or seen. Bundle this all up in a plot that makes no sense and is all over the place, and you've got yourself a terrible movie. Also, if you want to watch this dubbed, the voice acting is terrible, but I'm not marking the movie down for that since it was originally meant to be watched in Japanese and most anime dubs suck anyway. If you can appreciate this movie for the animation alone, it might be worth a watch, but if you mainly care about characters and plot, I'd definitely give this a hard pass.

It doesn't feel like it does much different from what we've already seen from the series, and the animation is, for the most part, not much higher in quality. Both of those are key if you want your film to feel like it's stepping things up. That being said, even though it may not be great, it's certainly not bad, either. Picking up right where we left off, the quality throughout is consistent with the first season: that means the story remains engaging and the animation is still better than most which makes fight scenes very fun to watch. There are two things, however, that really push ‚ÄòMugen Train' into above average territory: 1) the ability to spend two hours building up a new character and presenting his backstory, something that proves important when it comes to how much of an impact the ending has; 2) the animation and directing during the final fight. These two things combined make for a finale that is epic, satisfying, and moving in equal measure.

The highest grossing film in Japan is no easy feat to achieve, yet Mugen Train demonstrates that it deserves this spot with a film adaptation of the Demon Slayer anime/manga that brings everything fans would come to expect from the series, but with a noticeably bigger budget. The high production value is noticeable from the very first scene, with better quality animation (not that it was anything less than stellar in the series). Speaking of which, from the beginning to the ending of the film, the action packed story wastes no time launching us back into the Demon Slayer world when season 1 ended and the film moves at a breakneck pace. However, this isn't too jarring for those who didn't watch the series (though it helps a lot). The rest of the film is gets even better as it goes, with  impressive voicework and animation that really shines in the final act. The action set pieces are breathtaking and the film ends on a high note. There is also a mostly emotionally investing storyline, but does falter due to writing issues.
 Significantly the second act is where problems arise. The film rushes too quickly past touching moments in the first act to leap into the action of the second act, ruining any sort of emotional investment during the following sequences. There are also numerous random plot conveniences introduced, which seem interesting in concept but weak in execution. The animation quality is also inconsistent here.
The first act and the finale of the film really carry this movie, as well as the technical marvel of the film.
